body: fyi `KYMATIO_BACKEND_2D=skcuda` works and even `KYMATIO_BACKEND=skcuda KYMATIO_BACKEND_3D=torch` works
I would vote for (2), that is, make it non-functional when `skcuda` backend is chosen and raise an error when instantiating (or calling `forward()`).

I'm also voting for (2).

Otherwise, if we choose (1), then skcuda users will suddenly get errors of the like of
```
AttributeError: module 'kymatio' has no attribute 'scattering3d'
```
which is not informative enough for them to change their backend.

If you want I can add skcuda backend for 3D. I did it on pyscatharm, I have a speedup of 15%. It only concerns the Cdgmm function. It'a also possible to remove skcuda dependency if you copy the few necessary files as I did in pyscatharm : https://github.com/louity/pyscatharm/tree/master/scatharm/skcuda_utils
@louity that would probably be the best solution, assuming it doesn't take too much time. The 15% reduction is similar to what we see in 1D and can always be improved upon later.
@eickenberg  should I make a fork from eickenberg/kymatio or kymatio/kymatio  to make the PR ?

Cool, thanks very much @louity for adding this backend!

As far as I know the main speed-up due to skcuda/cupy backend in the 2D version comes from the kernel implementation of the fourier downsampling.

Do you have such an implementation for the 3D code and is this already in the 15% you mention?

Yes @eickenberg  In the 3D code it's 15% essentially because you have more complex multiplications than fourier transforms : in solid harmonic scattering transform, for 1 "convolution" with psi_l you have 2 FFT and 2L+1 complex multiplications, so speeding up complex multiplication really speeds up the whoel thing
I can't write a skcuda backend for 3d myself, but in the interest of time, what I can do is have Kymatio return a `NotImplementedError` if `KYMATIO_BACKEND=skcuda`.

that would be OK if it throws at instantiation, but not OK if it throws that at import. It would render this environment variable useless until that backend is implemented.

So +1 for `NotImplementedError` at instantiation of a 3D object with inexistent backend.

> In the 3D code it's 15% essentially because you have more complex multiplications than fourier transforms : in solid harmonic scattering transform, for 1 "convolution" with psi_l you have 2 FFT and 2L+1 complex multiplications, so speeding up complex multiplication really speeds up the whoel thing

That makes sense, thanks
OK, I'm tagging this issue (skcuda backend by @louity) for 0.2.0 and will raise another one re: NotImplementedError
